FacilityName: Peach Orchard Road Water Treatment Plant #1

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.      As Employees of Augusta-Richmond County Utilities Department, we have the responsibility to
         manage the operations to protect human health and the environment. Sound health, safety, and the 
         environment practices are an integral part of our everyday job requirements.

        In recognition of this responsibility, we will correct any unsound health, safety, and envirnmenttal
        practices or conditions, or call them to the attention of those who will do so, as soon as they are
        identified. We will:

       .  Conduct our operations in compliance with all laws and regulations.
       .  Conduct periodic assessments of our operations to ensure compliance and reduce risks.
       .  Establish health, safety, and environmental performance practices that apply risk management and
          and loss control principles to our operations.
       .  Provide education and training regarding laws, regulations, policies, and procedures to protect 
          human health and the environment.
       .  Cooperate with our trade groups, governmental agencies, and others to develop effective,
          reasonable rules and regulations to protect human health and the environment.

2.      Our goal is to provide a safe and dependable supply of drinking water that meets all federal and state
         regulations while protecting the human health of our neighbors and protect the environment.

         Our groundwater comes from twenty-eight wells and is treated in two plants.  Water enters Plant #1 
         and passes through an aerator that strips volatile organics out of the water. After aeration, the 
         following chemicals are added to the water.  Limes is added to increase the pH and alkalinity of the
         water. Fluoride is added for dental health, Phosphate is added for corrosion control and finally 
         CHLORINE is added for disinfection purposes.

3.       The worst case release scenario for a regulated substance from the #1 W

ater  Treatment Plant
          would be the failure of a pressurized chlorine cylinder, and the sudden release of it's contents.
          If full, the cylinder would release 2000 pounds of chlorine in 10 minutes. The distance to the
         toxic endpoint  would be 0.9 miles.  This distance was determined by EPA's RMP*Comp
         software.

        The alternative release scenario (ARS) for chlorine would be the shearing off of the liquid valve
        from the cylinder and releasing 2000 pounds of chlorine in 15 minutes. The distance to the toxic
        endpoint  would be 0.2 miles as determined by the RMP*Com software.

4.     The #1 Groundwater Treatment Plant has not had a reportable accidental releases of Chlorine (3ppm)
        in the last five years.

5.     Emergency Response Program

        Training and preperation......
        
        . Plant Emergency Response Plan
        . Emergency Response Team available 24 hours per day
        . Emergenct Response Team trained in Hazardous Materials.
        . Participate with simulation drills conducted in plant area.
       
         If a Release Occurs...

        . Chlorine detector will sound alarm.
        . Emergency Response Team can be activated.
        . Emergency Response Equipment available in  Plant and Office locations.
        . Ability to immediately request off-site emergency mutual aid assistance.
